summary: A confidential letter submitted to Judge Alison J. Nathan in support of Ghislaine Maxwell's bail application. The author, who does not identify themselves by name, attests to Maxwell's character, denies allegations against her, explains her need to hide from the press and vigilantes, and offers to co-sign a bond and provide 24/7 custody if she is released.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the bail hearing and character reference. The author defends her character, denies all allegations, and explains her actions as motivated by fear of the press and vigilantes, not guilt.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell to whom this confidential letter is addressed.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as 'the late Mr. Epstein' to contrast his legal strategy (taking the Fifth) with Maxwell's (submitting to depositions).

connections.description: Implicitly connected as co-accused in related matters; the author contrasts Epstein's legal strategy with Maxwell's.
The author claims a long-standing personal relationship, having known Maxwell since she was growing up, trusts her with children, and is willing to co-sign a bond and provide 24/7 custody.

events.title: The Sun offers bounty for Ghislaine Maxwell
events.description: The UK newspaper The Sun offered a £10,000 bounty for information leading them to Ghislaine Maxwell, which the letter author describes as 'extremely shocking and scary' and 'incitement to violence'.

keyFacts: An anonymous author submits a character reference and bail support letter for Ghislaine Maxwell, offering to co-sign a $1.5 million bond and provide 24/7 personal custody.
The author claims Maxwell went into hiding due to fear of press, vigilantes, and death threats, not to evade authorities, citing a specific £10,000 bounty offered by The Sun newspaper.
The letter asserts Maxwell never left the United States after Jeffrey Epstein's death, contrary to widespread media rumors placing her in various international locations.
The author contrasts Maxwell's legal approach (submitting to depositions) with that of Jeffrey Epstein (taking the Fifth Amendment).
The document reveals Maxwell's stated motivation for staying in the U.S. was to be close to her husband and fight the case.
